caption:
The photograph captures an indoor scene, likely within a railway or transit office, marked by a sign that reads "CONDUCTORS." The image shows two men focused on their tasks. On the right, a man wearing a conductor's uniform complete with a cap is standing at a counter, writing on a clipboard resting on an open, well-thumbed book or folder. He is an older gentleman, paying close attention to his work.

On the left, inside the office framed by a window, another man can be seen. He is wearing glasses and a light-colored, short-sleeved shirt. He stands behind the counter, looking down at some papers or a book, projecting an aura of concentration and professionalism.

The office is equipped with simple, functional furniture including a wooden counter where interactions take place. Above the window, there is a fluorescent light fixture that illuminates the scene. The overall lighting and details suggest a focus on efficiency and clarity within the workspace. The ambience relayed by the photograph is one of orderly activity and dedicated work typical of a railway or similar setting.
title: Conductor checks scheduling information at the Wenatchee, Washington, depot for the Expo '74 passenger train which makes a 10 minute stop enroute from Spokane to Seattle. Amtrak assumed responsibility for most U.S. intercity rail passenger service in 1971 and reversed a decline in riders. Use of the track is leased from the nation's railroads.
